stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on designing the 'Oil Rig' level, focusing on layout, scale, and performance. The main activities included brainstorming a new boss fight from scratch, resulting in the 'Oil Blargg' concept, and discussing visual polish like new fog and lighting. The stream also touched upon Kaze's game design philosophy, project timelines, and his relationship with Nintendo.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is in a 'polishing phase' for the game, which involved updating the fog to be blue instead of black and improving the lighting on Mario's model.
development_findings.quote: I decided to update the fog and I think this looks a lot better... I also updated the lights. I think the light is really cool now.

development_findings.summary: An update to the underlying 'libultra' code broke the cannon's aiming reticle, prompting Kaze to decide on a complete rewrite of the feature because he considered the original implementation 'atrocious'.
development_findings.quote: I kind of updated all the lib ultra things including the translation matrix thing and kind of broke the old rectacle... I'm just gonna remake that whole cannon rectacle anyway because the way it's rendered is atrocious.

development_findings.summary: A new camera collision system has been implemented that intelligently prevents the camera from being obstructed by external level geometry while ignoring internal elements like decorative posts.
development_findings.quote: Only outside level geometry is gonna block the camera like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates the project is two-thirds complete after nearly three years of work, with a projected timeline of at least another year and a half until release.
development_findings.quote: We are only two-thirds through the game and it's been like almost three years now... realistically it's still gonna be at least like a year and a half.

development_findings.summary: The team decided on a new boss for the oil rig level: a Blargg (a lava monster from Yoshi's Island) made of oil, as it fits both the level theme and the game's Yoshi's Island motif.
development_findings.quote: I think the oil block is really our play here. Because blocks are really famous in Yoshi's Island. They're everywhere. And oil block just fits so well to this level.

development_findings.summary: The game will be open-source, but the code will only be released a week or two after the game's launch to prevent spoilers and potential issues with Nintendo.
development_findings.quote: It will be open source once it is released but not before because I would just be leaking my entire mod.

development_findings.summary: To make the Oil Rig world feel larger, Kaze decided to add an interconnected underwater/below-sea-level area accessible from multiple points, which would act as a quasi-quick travel system.
The team brainstormed and tentatively settled on 'Oozing Oil Operation' as the alliterative name for the oil rig level.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the game's unique physics will require speedrunners to unlearn their standard Mario 64 muscle memory, effectively making it a full commitment to play at a high level.
context_findings.quote: The thing with this hack is that the physics are so different that you're going to unlearn your normal Mario 64 muscle memory. If you are a speedrunner and you want to speedrun this game, you kind of have to commit to only speedrunning this game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a design principle of avoiding the temptation to create custom mechanics that replace Mario's core moveset, believing that a reliance on the original moveset leads to better ROM hacks.
context_findings.quote: It's very tempting to use our custom coding instead of the Mario moveset, and I think that often leads to poor ROM hacks. I want to avoid that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes games like Pikmin 2 that he feels are linear and don't offer meaningful player choice, contrasting it with his enjoyment of the freedom in 'Tears of the Kingdom'.
context_findings.quote: You have no freedom. You're basically just like a worker drone. You're not actually playing a game. You're just doing what you're being told.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels less threatened by Nintendo's legal actions recently, stating he has successfully contested their YouTube claims and had his content reinstated.
context_findings.quote: I'm even contesting their YouTube claims and they're putting me back online. I'm not really that worried about Nintendo anymore.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains that the project, and his modding work in general, has evolved from a hobby into a business through YouTube ad revenue.
context_findings.quote: It started purely as a hobby, but it slowly turned into, like, business because I started making money from it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals he has a full-time job at Gears for Breakfast and spends his days off working on the project, indicating a significant personal time investment.
context_findings.quote: I have Monday off, so I may have a lot of time to work. Yeah, that's what I do on my day off, I work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal conspiracy theory that extreme wealth transforms a person into a non-human 'entity'.
context_findings.quote: At some point when you have so much money at your disposal, you cease to become human anymore. You are just an entity that exists with too much money.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a visual mockup for a complex glowing dial effect, which Kaze noted looked cool but presented a technical programming challenge to implement efficiently.
Biobak's role includes polishing and beautifying the 3D models Kaze creates, which Kaze credits as a major reason for the game's improved visual quality compared to the demo.
biobak.quote: He like whenever I finish a model he's looking over it again. It makes it a lot prettier. That is part of the reason that this looks so much better than the demo.

biobak.summary: During a brainstorming session for a boss, Biobak sarcastically suggested a 'huge metal pipe,' highlighting a moment of levity and back-and-forth creative humor within the team.
biobak.quote: Huge metal pipe? Oh my god, that's an insane idea. Why did no one think of a huge metal pipe before? Thank you, Biobak. That is so refreshing to hear.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze clarified that while she is often quiet on stream, she is actively involved in helping with the project in the background. Her title is Animator.
zeina.quote: I'm usually just helping him doing stuff. Usually she's a loudmouth.

zeina.summary: Zeina is working on animations for both Bowser and various NPCs, including the Buzzy Beetles.
zeina.quote: Is there any more Bowser's animations that you need or can I send these off and work on the NPCs?

zeina.summary: Zeina participated in level design discussions, asking for clarification on how 'inside the cave' Kaze wanted Bowser's castle to be.

key_stories.title: The Oil Blargg Boss Concept
key_stories.summary: The team needed a boss for the oil rig level and went through a collaborative brainstorming process. After rejecting several standard Mario enemies, they landed on creating a new boss, an 'Oil Blargg,' inspired by Yoshi's Island, and designed a unique fight mechanic around chasing it with a bar of soap.
key_stories.challenge: The oil rig level needed a final boss. The initial concept was vague, just requiring a 'big, fat, burly guy' to act as a 'strike breaker' against protesting minions.
key_stories.process: The team brainstormed numerous ideas, including Boom Boom and Kamek, which Kaze rejected. He expressed a strong preference for an enemy from Yoshi's Island to fit the game's theme. After the 'Oil Blargg' idea was suggested, the discussion shifted to its mechanics, exploring how to damage it. The idea of using soap was raised, leading to a cinematic concept of riding a soap bar to ram into the boss.
key_stories.outcome: The team settled on creating a new boss: an oil-based version of the 'Blargg' enemy from Yoshi's Island. They designed a full fight concept where the player rides a bar of soap to chase and 'clean' the boss, causing it to shrink and eventually be defeated.
key_stories.key_quote: If we had a big, fat dude from Yoshi's Island, that would be perfect.

key_stories.title: Expanding the Oil Rig Level
key_stories.summary: Feeling the oil rig level was too small and linear, Kaze devised a solution to expand it without physically enlarging the main platform. He conceptualized an interconnected underwater area accessible from multiple points, adding a layer of exploration and making the world feel significantly larger.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was concerned that the oil rig level felt too linear and small, consisting of only a few distinct paths and not much exploration.
key_stories.process: Kaze vocalized his dissatisfaction with the current level layout. He analyzed the mission flow and realized it was very linear. He then proposed adding an entirely new dimension to the level by creating an underwater area that connects different parts of the overworld, adding depth and encouraging exploration.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a new plan to make the level feel larger and more interconnected. He decided to add a large, explorable 'below sea level' area with its own points of interest, accessible via multiple distinct entrances scattered across the main level, effectively serving as a hub or quick travel system.
key_stories.key_quote: The overworld feels so small to me now. I don't like that. I don't like how small it feels, how can we fix that?
